1.0     EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

Affected employees will be consulted on the development and conduct of this plan and all elements required by the PSM regulation. Affected employees will also be provided access to all information required to be developed. Specific participation requirements are listed in the sections that follow.


2.0     PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION (PSI)

2.1     Written information has been developed for processes covered by this regulation. The purpose of written process safety information is to enable all persons involved in operating the process to identify and fully understand the hazards posed by the process. The PSI will be completed for the support of and prior to conducting What-If Analysis, the development of operating procedures and the development or conduct of operator, maintenance and contractor training.

The Production, Engineering, and Maintenance Departments will ensure that the information required by this section is up-to-date and made available to all affected employees.

2.2. The Plant Engineer will ensure that the PSI package is created before Process Hazards Analyses (PHAs) are performed as outlined in section 3.0 of this procedure.


2.3    The Plant Engineer will ensure the PSI package is maintained current and made available to those developing, conducting and reviewing:
 
A. Maintenance and operating procedures and training documents.
 
B. Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs).
 
C. Management of Change (MOC) activities.
 
D. Investigations. 
 
E. Contractor coordination.

2.4        The PSI package must be comprehensive to support an accurate assessment of the fire and explosion characteristics, reactivity hazards, safety and health of employees and the corrosion/erosion effects of the process equipment and monitoring tools. In addition to a narrative description of the PSI, the package will include at least:

A.    Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) for each hazardous chemical as required by the OSHA Hazard Communication (HAZCOM) regulation 1910.1200 and the site's written HAZCOM program. The site EH&S Manager will ensure that all required MSDSs are complete and available to all affected employees and contractors.

B.    Any supplemental chemical information necessary including chemical intermediates, over-pressure and runaway reaction hazards.

C.        Information concerning the technology of the process. This information shall include at least the following:

1. A block flow that illustrates the major process equipment and interconnecting process flow lines.
2. Process chemistry.
3. Maximum intended inventory for process chemicals.
4. Safe upper and lower limits for temperatures, pressures, flows, and compositions (limits beyond which would be considered safety upset conditions).
5. A qualitative estimate of the consequences of deviations that could occur if operating beyond the established process limits, including safety and health effects on affected personnel.

D.    Process equipment information shall be documented in the PSI package include:

1. Materials of construction.
 
2. Piping and instrument diagrams (P&ID's) used to describe the relationships between equipment and instrumentation. P&ID's will include this and other relevant information including:

A. The information for the piping designer and engineering staff. 
B. Main flow streams including valves. 
C. Pressures and temperatures on all feed and product lines within all major vessels and in and out of headers and heat exchangers.
D. Points of pressure and temperature control.
E. Construction materials.
F. Pump capacities and pressure heads. 
G. Compressor horsepower. 
H. Vessel design pressures and temperatures.
I. Major control loops.
J. Key utilities.

3. Electrical classifications.
4. Relief system design documentation and the design basis.
5. Ventilation system design.
6. Documented codes and standards used or relied upon in the design of the process equipment.
7. Material and energy balances (for processes built after May 26, 1992).
8. Safety systems (interlocks, detection and suppression systems).
9. Documentation shall include that the process equipment complies with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.
10. For existing equipment designed and built to codes no longer in general use, the Granite Falls Plant Engineer will determine and document that the equipment is designed, maintained, inspected, tested, and operated in a safe manner.


3.0    PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

3.1     The What-If Analysis has been selected as the appropriate process hazard analysis methodology for Tenneco Packaging - NAPP, Granite Falls.
A.  Definition:  What-If Analysis can be described as a systematized group of "What-If" questions intended to:  1) recognize and evaluate the potential failure of a product/process and its effects, 2) identify actions which could eliminate or reduce the chance of the potential failure occurring, and 3) document the process.

3.3     The site manager and Plant Engineer will resolve any scheduling conflicts or concerns with the appropriate department management.

3.4     The Plant Engineer will ensure the following information is provided, as a minimum, to the What-If  team:

A.    The PSI package (section 4 above).

B.    Any previous incident(s) which had a potential for catastrophic consequences in the workplace.

3.5     The Plant Engineer will ensure the final reports and corrective action plans with completion schedules are communicated with operating, maintenance and other employees whose work assignments are in the process and who may be affected by the recommendations or actions. Final reports will be made available in the Production Office and PSM Manual.

3.6     All PHA reports, corrective action plans and schedules, corresponding closure documentation and the employee review documentation will be retained by the Granite Falls Plant Egineer for the life of the process.


4.0 OPERATING PROCEDURES (SOPs)

4.1     The Granite Falls employees will create, implement and maintain written SOPs that provide clear instruction to safely conduct process operations consistent with the process safety information and shall address at least the following elements.

    The Production department has implemented written operat-ing procedures that provide instruction to safely conduct process operations consistent with the process safety information.   The procedures shall be readily accessible to employees who work in or maintain the process.

A. Steps for each operating phase;

(i) Start-up under normal operations, experimental runs, turn around or emergency situations;

(ii) Normal operation and shutdown;

(iii) Temporary operations.

B. Operating Limits:

(i) Consequences of deviation; and

(ii) Steps required to correct or avoid deviation.

C. Safety and health considerations:

(i) Properties of, and hazard presented by, the chemicals used in the process;

(ii) Precautions necessary to prevent exposure including engineering controls, administrative controls, and personal protective equipment;

(iii) Control measures to be taken if physical contact or airborne exposure occurs;

(iv) Quality control for raw materials and control of hazardous chemical inventory levels; and

(v) Any special or unique hazards.

D. Safety systems and their functions.

4.2     SOP content will be reviewed by the plant PSM team prior to finalizing any procedure.

4.3     The procedures shall be readily accessible to all employees or contractors who work in or maintain the process.

4.4     Operating procedures shall be reviewed and updated as often as necessary to ensure that they reflect current operating practice. Procedures will be updated when there is a change in the chemicals, technology, equipment or facilities used in the process as required by Management of Change.

4.5     All procedures will be revalidated and approved to be current and accurate, at least once per year by the plant PSM team.

4.6     Operations and Maintenance supervision shall implement safe work practices to provide for the control of hazards during operations. These include, but are not limited to, energy control procedures (Lockout/Tagout, Electrical Safety, opening process equipment or piping), facility and extrusion area access control, Confined Space Entry, JSAs, transition meetings, safety postings or bulletins and other safety requirements.



5.0 TRAINING

5.1     The plant PSM team and Safety Coordinator will develop training packages for each covered process (or extrusion line) when the PSI, SOPs or other required information is different from another process or line.

5.2    Personnel operating the process will demonstrate full understanding of SOPs. Each employee involved in operating a process will be approved as having the required knowledge in the operations of that process.      

5.3    Newly assigned employees and contractors will be trained in an overview of the process and the operating procedures. An emphasis shall be placed on the specific hazards and safe work practices applicable to the employee's job task.  

5.4    Refresher training shall be provided to each employee involved in operating a process, as often as necessary, to assure the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.

5.5    Employees and contractors will be trained as the initial or revised training becomes available.

5.6    Training will be reviewed and revised as often as necessary by the plant PSM team to ensure that training is accurate and reflects current requirements. Training will be reviewed as follows:
A.    Yearly to ensure the necessary skills, knowledge and routines are being properly understood, implemented and producing the desired results.  
B.    When there are changes in the process safety information or operating procedures.
C.     When training evaluations indicate a need for revision.

5.7    Supplemental training shall be provided to each employee or contractor involved in operating or maintaining the covered process(es) yearly to assure the each employee or contractor understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.

5.8     Supplemental training shall also be conducted per the Operator training procedures when changes are made to the process to ensure the changes and effects on the job tasks are understood.

5.9     Employees involved in operating the process have been consulted and have determined the frequency of refresher training for each package. Refresher training has been determined to be required every year.

5.10     Documentation of all initial, supplemental and refresher trainings shall be maintained in the PSM Manual with a copy of this manual located in the Production Office. Training shall be documented in writing with the inclusion of:
- the employee's name
- trainer's signature or initials
- dates of training


6.0  MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

Management of Change is the system required to be implemented for any permanent or temporary (experimental-trials etc.) changes (other than replacements-in-kind" that affect any portion of the PSI, SOPs or facilities that affect any covered process(es).   This procedure is required for internal changes to Process Safety Management Process from the Butane Tank supply through the California room and any externally recommended changes.

The Management of Change checklist will be initiated and approved prior to implementing any changes being introduced or introducing any new chemicals to the process. 

7.0.  PRE-START UP SAFETY REVIEWS (PSSRs)

7.1     PSSRs will be performed on all new facilities and when modifications require a change in the process safety information prior to the introduction of any highly hazardous chemicals to the process.

7.2     The review shall confirm that:

A. A PHA has been performed on new facilities.
 
B.    Construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications.

C.    ALL PSI, safety, operating, maintenance, safe practices and emergency procedures are fully developed, evaluated and adequate for use.

D.    ALL training is completed.

7.3     The PSSR checklist will be used for documenting the review and kept on file with the plant Project Coordinator.


8.0  MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

8.1    This procedure categorizes maintenance into two areas: scheduled and unscheduled maintenance.   Work performed through the preventive maintenance schedule or projects is scheduled maintenance.   Work performed as the result of a breakdown is unscheduled maintenance. 

8.2     This section applies to the following process equipment:

A. Pressure vessels and storage tanks.
 
B. Piping systems (including components such as valves).
 
C. Relief and vent systems and devices.
 
D. Emergency shutdown systems.
 
E. Controls including monitoring devices, sensors, alarms, and interlocks.
 
F. Pumps.
 
8.3 SCHEDULED MAINTENANCE:
Weekly/Monthly Preventive Maintenance (PM) Lists and Projects are used to schedule maintenance, improvements or calibration of manufacturing equipment or support equipment.


9.0 CONTRACTORS

9.1  This section applies to contractors performing maintenance or repair, experimental trials, turnaround, major renovations or specialty work on or adjacent to a covered process.  Tenneco Packaging, Granite Falls, Contractor Compliance with Safety and Health Rules Procedure will be used in conjunction with the performance of this section.

9.2     A contractor's safety performance and programs will be evaluated by project manager as a part of the contractor selection process.  

9.3     The appropriate project manager shall advise the contract supervisor of the known potential fire, explosion or toxic release hazards related to the scope of work and the process. Any hazards presented by contractor work will also be addressed.

9.4     The appropriate project manager will ensure the contractors are instructed in the applicable safe work practices and emergency action plans.

9.5     The Safety Coordinator shall maintain contractor illness and injury logs related to the contractor's work in the process areas.  (This will be done on an OSHA 200 Log sheet marked "Contractor Log", and will be kept in the Safety files.)

9.6     The project manager shall periodically evaluate the performance of contractors and ensure the provisions of the Tenneco Packaging, Granite Falls, Contractor Compliance with Safety and Health Rules are being fulfilled.  Evaluations are to be conducted while work is being performed deviations noted on the Safe Work Permit.

9.7     Contractor access to the plant and operating units will be controlled by the project manager through the use of the Safe Work Permit.


10.0     EMERGENCY PLANNING AND RESPONSE

Emergency planning and response will be in accordance with the requirements of the Tenneco Packaging-NAPP, Granite Falls site Emergency Response Plan.


11.0         INCIDENT INVESTIGATIONS

11.1     All incidents involving an event that resulted in or could have resulted in a release of a highly hazardous chemical, serious injury or property damage will be investigated per Tenneco Packaging, Granite Falls plant Incident Investigation Process and Incident Reporting Procedures.

11.2     All investigation findings, corrective actions and corrective action schedules will be reviewed with the affected employees and contractors. These reviews will be documented and maintained in a central tracking system maintained by the Safety Coordinator. Final investigation reports, corrective action schedules and closure documentation will be maintained by the Safety Coordinator for five years.


12.0 COMPLIANCE AUDITS

12.1    A team shall be established to evaluate compliance to the requirements of this regulation at least every two years.

12.2     The Plant Engineer, or designate, will assign a team that will consist of knowledgeable persons from each department responsible for the performance of this regulation.

12.3     The team will use checklists which will be provided by the Plant Engineer.

12.4     An audit report will be issued to the Plant Manager, the affected Unit Manager, Safety Coordinator, and the Maintenance Manager detailing the findings.  The findings will be promptly addressed, corrective action scheduled and entered into the PSM implementation plan to ensure corrective actions are taken in a timely manner.

12.5     The final report, corrective action and schedules will be reviewed with the affected employees and contractors.    Documentation formats for audits will follow standard auditing practices and corrective actions may be in the form of eight discipline reports,  gant charts, or other communication and shall include responsibilities as well as timetables.

12.6     The site Plant Engineer shall retain the two (2) most recent compliance audit reports along with the documentation of the affected employee and contractor review, corrective action schedules and closure documentation.

 13.0   REVIEW/REVISION

13.1     This plan will be reviewed annually by the Plant Engineer and the plant PSM team. Any revisions will be presented to the site management team for approval.

13.2     All revisions will be reviewed with affected employees.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Tenneco Packaging - NAPP, Granite Falls, NC

1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

We at Tenneco are strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is inherent to a comprehensive accidental release prevention program in place that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  Unforeseeably, if such a release does occur, we are completely coordinated with the Caldwell County Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) and the Granite Falls Fire Department to provides highly trained emergency response personnel to control and mitigate the effects of the release.


2. THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Our facilitys primary activities encompass the manufacturing of polyethylene foam products that is used as packaging material. We have one regulated substance present at our facility, butane.  This regulated substance is used as a blowing agent at our facility. 

The maximum inventory of butane at our facility is 75,000 lbs.

3. THE WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND THE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO, INCLUDING ADMINISTRATIVE CONTROLS AND MITIGATION MEASURES TO LIMIT THE DISTANCES FOR EACH REPORTED SCENARIO

To evaluate the worst case scenario and alternative release scenario, we have used equations from the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA's) RMP Guidance for Propane Storage Facilities. The following paragraphs provide details of the chosen scenarios.

The worst case release scenario submitted is for a Level 3 flammable substance which involves a catastrophic release from a butane storage tank.  The scenario involves the release of 45,000 lbs. of butane.  Passive mitigation systems such as dikes have not been considered when evaluating this worst case scenario.  For this scenario

, it is assumed that the entire quantity is released as a vapor, which finds an ignition source, with 10 percent of the released quantity participating in a vapor cloud explosion.  Under the worst case weather conditions, the consequence distance from the explosion of the vapor cloud to an overpressure of 1 pound per square inch (psi) is 0.3 miles.

The alternative release scenario submitted is for a Level 3 flammable substance which involves a release of butane from an overfilled storage tank.  The scenario involves the release of 9700 lb. of butane which is assumed to result in a pool fireThe maximum distance from the center of the pool where people can potentially receive second degree burns from a 40-second exposure is 0.1 miles.

4. THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Our facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  In addition, we have one process at our facility which is subject to the Occupational Safety & Health Administration  (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard under 29 CFR 1910.119 and we have submitted a Title V air permit application. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the accidental release prevention program that are in place at Tenneco.  

Process Safety Information
Tenneco maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with the covered process.

Process Hazard Analysis
Tenneco conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  "What If" methodology is used to carry out these analyses.  These studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and revalidated at a regular interval of 5 years and when major changes are made to the covere

d process.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures
For the purposes of safely conducting activities within the covered process, Tenneco maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as startup, shutdown, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown and emergency operations.  The information is reviewed on a regular basis and is readily accessible to operators involved in the process.

Training
Tenneco has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating components of the covered process are competent in the operating procedures associated with these components.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.

Mechanical Integrity
Tenneco performs documented maintenance checks on covered process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes but is not limited to storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.  The maintenance operations are done by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices; and these personnel are provided specialized training as needed. 

Management of Change
Written procedures are in place at Tenneco to manage changes in covered process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in the covered process conditions are promptly made aware of and given training to deal with the modification.

Pre-startup Reviews
Pre-start up safety reviews related to additions and modifications to the covered process are conducted as a regular practice at Tenneco.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipme

nt, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits
Tenneco will continue to conduct periodic audits to ensure that the provisions set forth under the RMP and PSM rules are being implemented.   Any corrective actions required as a result of the audits will be undertaken in a safe and prompt manner. 

Incident Investigation
Tenneco promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions that would prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports are retained at our facility for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation
Tenneco truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and they actively participate in process safety management.  In addition, Tenneco employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP and PSM rules, including information resulting from process hazard analyses.

Contractors
On occasion, Tenneco hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough safety performance evaluation of the contractor is carried out. Tenneco has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related the contractor's work and the covered process.  Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.

5. FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Tenneco has an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.  As a result of Tenneco's stringent release prevention programs, there have been no significant accidental

releases during this period.

6. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

Tenneco maintains a written emergency evacuation plan for the safety of our employees during accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations and notification of local emergency response agencies  Tenneco employees do not respond to the emergency.

Emergency notification equipment is regularly inspected and serviced to ensure proper functioning.  Upon modification of the covered process, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes within the covered process that would require a modified emergency response.

7. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

To enhance our continuous improvement in occupational safety and health, we conduct monthly general safety safety planning meetings which includes employee participation.
